title: Smart Pill Dispenser — STM32-Based Medication Management System
overview: A school project: an STM32-based smart pill dispenser designed for both hospital and home-care medication routines. After one-time setup, it automatically dispenses at scheduled times to reduce missed or double doses. In hospitals, it supports staff by making routine dispensing more consistent; at home, it helps elderly patients and caregivers follow daily medication schedules more easily and track whether dispensing happened.
overviewPoints: One-time schedule setup (supports multiple dispensing times per day).
RTC timekeeping for accurate scheduled dispensing.
Servo-driven dispensing with a 3D-printed guiding mechanism.
IR/PIR sensing to confirm dispensing activity and detect presence.
OLED + keypad for setup and status.
problem: Some patients (especially elderly users) may forget to take medication or accidentally take it twice when relying on memory or manual pill boxes. In home-care settings, caregivers can also misread the schedule or give a dose at the wrong time, especially when managing multiple medications and busy routines.
solution: The device uses RFID for authorised access, an RTC to keep time and run scheduled dispensing, and a servo mechanism with sensors to dispense pills and confirm activity at the scheduled time.
targetUsers: Elderly patients taking multiple medications, and caregivers/healthcare workers who need a simple way to support medication adherence.
impact: The prototype improved consistency of scheduled dispensing during testing and helped caregivers check whether dispensing happened as planned.
tech: RTC-based scheduling (one-time setup) for automatic dispensing at configured times.
3D-printed housing and custom dispensing parts to guide pills and support the mechanism.
Servo-driven dispensing mechanism to release pills on schedule.
Sensors (IR/PIR) to detect dispensing activity and user presence.
OLED + keypad for setup, status display, and on-device configuration.
responsibilities: Developed STM32 firmware in C++ to control the full system.
Integrated RFID authentication, RTC scheduling, sensors (IR/PIR), and servo motor control.
Configured STM32 peripherals such as GPIO, timers, and interrupts for real-time behaviour.
Troubleshot firmware logic and electrical wire connections (power, signal, grounding) to stabilise sensor readings and servo operation.
Worked with teammates to test and verify the prototype end-to-end.
features: STM32, Embedded C++, RFID, RTC, IR Sensor, PIR Sensor, Servo Motor, OLED Display, Keypad
learnings: How to build an embedded prototype from concept to working system (hardware + firmware + testing).
Practical STM32 embedded C++ development with multiple sensors and actuators.
Designing and assembling a dispensing mechanism (including 3D-printed parts) and aligning it for reliable operation.
Using timers/interrupts (and RTC scheduling) to support real-time, automatic operation.
Troubleshooting both embedded software and hardware issues (wiring connections, timing, sensor noise, mechanical alignment).
Testing the full system to verify real-world behaviour and reliability.

title: Supermarket Self-Checkout System — IoT Kiosk + Web Platform
tech: Item scanning and cart management on the kiosk.
Persistent cart synced to a web application.
Containerised backend for easy deployment and rollback.
heroAlt: Supermarket self-checkout kiosk with keypad and LCD
problem: Conventional manned checkout counters create queues and require more staff during peak hours.
solution: Built a kiosk that lets customers scan items, manage their cart locally, then sync to a web backend for payment and receipt.
responsibilities: Maintained the Dockerised backend and database.
Monitored Raspberry Pi kiosk health and performed on-site troubleshooting.
Coordinated integration testing between kiosk and web interfaces.
features: Python Backend, SQL / MariaDB, Raspberry Pi, Docker, REST APIs, Web Frontend
